interlinear-text.item: Mamadkarim Dawlyatmamad 50 y.o., peasant village Ishmyrg (Afghanistan) Recorded 7.13.1969
Translation proofed by Nicole, QUESTIONS about 4.4-4.6, 26.12

phrase.item: There was a king.
He was the king of seven lands.
He had no children.
When he reached the age of sixty, he (said) to his wife: "To whom will this kingdom go, who will rule it?"
The king (then) went off to travel.
He made it to a valley (and) happened upon a small dwelling.
The king opened the door, and one qalandar (dervish) was sitting there.
The king greeted him, (and) the dervish answered the greeting.
The king began to lament: "I have no son, if I should die one of these days, who will inherit the kingdom, who will rule (it)?"
The dervish advised: "Give up your wealth, give up (your) reign, and then you will attain a son."
The dervish gave the king one apple, (said): "Take this apple, share it with your wife and eat it!"
The king took the apple.
He returned home, divided this apple with his wife, (and) ate it.
Nine months later, a son was born to him.
He called him Shoidjon.
He gave all his wealth away to people. (As for himself) he began to live by alms.
He'd beg a cup of flour in some house or other, and live on that for a day.
One day, when the son had grown a little, he went off with the village kids to get firewood.
The Russian translation adds "Девять-десять ребят было." ("Nine or ten kids all in all."), with no corresponding Wakhi.
They prepared plenty of firewood, put all their loads aside, (and) laid out their lunchtime flatbreads before them.
Other kids had wheat flatbreads, (but) the king's son (had) a millet one.
They didn't eat the king's son's flatbread, (they) tossed it aside. [I WANT TO TALK TO HUSNIYA ABOUT 4.4-4.6]
They ate their own flatbreads, shouldered their loads, (and) went off (home).
(Meanwhile) the king's son picked up a piece of his own millet flatbread, held it close and wept bitterly.
And sleep came over him.
And it so happened that (suddenly) a stallion appeared before him.
The stallion was on it's own, with no people accompanying it.
The king's son was surprised that the stallion had no master.
He took him by the bridle, (and saw) there was a sack on him,
he untied it, (and) there was a change of clothes in the sack.
The king's son put on these clothes, mounted the stallion, whipped (him) once with a whip. (And then suddenly) the king's son's vision went dark.
It so happened that the stallion emerged into the Mysateh/Mysat' valley.
He whipped him (the horse) two or three times, hurting the stallion, who then spoke: "O king's son, get off me, dig (the ground) with your whip in front of my hoof, (and) you will see something!"
The king's son dismounted, (and) began to dig the spot pointed out by the stallion.
A door appeared.
He opened it.
The king's son entered the house, and there was a traveler of some kind sitting there.

They greeted each other, then the traveler said: "This stallion, oh king's son, along with (all your) clothes were sent to you by me. Don't be surprised [or bashful], (all this) doesn't belong to someone else, the stallion is your own and the clothes are your own!"
(Then) he gave the king's son a sword, (and said): "Anytime you find yourself in a bind, take out this sword, it will save you from a calamity.
But wherever this stallion might take you, obey him, follow him, follow him to the place he takes you, do not go back!
And also, king's son, I will give you one piece of advice: 'If you marry, then do not lie down to sleep with the wife for seven days!
And after seven days, you may lie down to sleep with her."
The traveler blessed the king's son, and the king's son was on his way.
Only by sundown did he make it to a city.
He entered the house of a crone.
(And) the crone told him: "I've got nothing to eat, you'll be hungry in the evening!"
The king's son said: "Today, mother, it's no matter, if something turns up, we'll eat, if not, we'll just betake ourselves to bed in peace!"
No food turned up, (so) they lay down to sleep.
(Suddenly) the crone said: "King's son, don't leave the house at night!"
The king's son agreed: "All right, I shan't come out."
At night the king's son got to thinking: "What did she mean by this?"
And it so happened that he left the house without asking the crone's permission. And here the king's son saw that at one end of the city, there was light, and in the other - darkness.
The king's son came back, walked through the door, locked it, the crone overheard, (and) said: "Now why did you leave the house, king's son, didn't I forbid you yesterday (to do so)?
You went out without my permission, I bet, since you were alone, (and) didn't know anything, you were frightened?"
The king's son said: "I wasn't frightened."
The crone asked: "What did you see, then?"
The king's son said: "What is this mystery, grandma: on one side of the city (there is) light, on the other (there is) darkness?"
The crone replied: "In our city, king's son, every day a dragon eats a girl, two bulls, and eighty flatbreads.
All the people have already given the dragon what was due, now it's our king's turn, (and) he's only got one daughter, no son.
The screams and wailing, and the darkness as well, were because of the king('s sacrfice).
But where there's light (and) rejoicing, their turn has already passed.
Morning came, the king's son left his stallion with the crone, took his sword, went off on foot into town.
He made it to a place - a body of water.
(It had) two plain trees on the shore, (and) under the plain trees, a house for girls, (and in it) one girl, chained up and tied to a plane tree.
There were also two bulls tied up and four baskets with flatbreads prepared.
The king's son said hello.
That girl who was chained up said: "Hello, where are you headed to, youth?

What made you come here? Keep going and be quick about it, because the dragon is about to crawl out (and) eat you, it would hurt me if he ate you in my stead. I've already been sentenced, my father could not bypass (his) turn to the people, (so) that's how I come to be tied up here."
The king's son said: "I will remain here with you, lass, I will finish (the dragon) and you will be freed!"
And the king's son remained with the girl.
A minute later, a dragon emerged from the water.
The girl began to cry, (and) said: "One head of the dragon has already emerged, king's son!"
The king's son calmed (her) down: "Don't worry!"
The girl lost consciousness.
The king's son took out his sword, (and) chopped off (it's) head. Another head emerged, he chopped it off as well. He chopped off all seven of the dragon's heads.
One half of the dead dragon remained in the water, the other half on land.
Then the girl regained consciousness, (and) said: "King's son, how did we remain alive? (How did) the dragon not eat us?"
The king's son said: "I killed the dragon, that's how, here are his heads, (and) here is his carcass!"
The king's son cut a strip from the dragon (skin), threaded (all) seven heads of the dragon (onto it), (and) hung (them) up on a plane tree.
He untied the girl, and the two bulls as well.
Then the king's son said: "Take the two bulls back with you, tell your father, "some man showed up, (and) he killed the dragon.
[You will know who he is because he will be able to] lift all these seven heads with one hand up onto the plane tree and lower them seven times to the earth.
His second [distinguishing] characteristic will be that his foot fits this [particular] shoe.
The third (will be) that his sword fits this scabbard, whoever's sword fits this scabbard [is he who slew the dragon].
Tell your father about these the three things." The king's son returned to that crone's house.
The king's daughter, she took her bulls, (and) went to her father.
The king, who was her father, asked: "You must have broken the chains and run off, (and) now the dragon will crawl out, devour (the entire) city!"

The king's daughter answered: "O father, some man appeared, he slew the dragon. He left behind three [clues as to his identity and said that] anyone who fits these those characteristics is the one who killed the dragon.
Do not believe anyone [who says it was them], if they do not have the three characteristics!"
‎‎The king and (his) people, (and) his daughter went to the body of water; (where he saw that) the dragon was dead.
The king rejoiced.
Then all sorts of people started coming from every direction, saying: "O king, I was the one who slew that dragon."
(First one), then another said: "I slew (it)."
The king's daughter repudiated (them) saying: "Whoever matches the three characteristics is the one who slew the dragon."
People asked: "What sort of characteristics?"
The king's daughter said: "First, he will be able to raise all seven heads with one hand seven times to the branch of the plane tree (and) lower (them) seven times to the ground.
Second, if he [truly did] slay the dragon, his foot will fit in this shoe.
And third, if he slew the dragon, his sword will fit in this scabbard.
These are his characterisitics!"
No matter how many people tried, (they) could not lift the dragon's heads, and (their) feet did not fit the shoe, and (their) swords did not fit the scabbard.
Finally (they) found [the very man they were looking for], the king's son named Shoidjon, in the house of the crone. [It was he who] slew the dragon.
(He) was led and introduced to the king.
The king's daughter said: "This is the man who slew it!"
The king's son lifted with one hand the seven heads, hung (them) on the branch (and) lowered to the ground again.
One characterisitic was thus demonstrated.
(Then) he stuck his foot into the shoe - a perfect fit.
He placed his sword into the scabbard - a match.
So all the people left.
The king led the youth into his house, and gave him his daughter (as a bride).
The wedding lasted seven days and nights, (as they) wined and dined the people.
(Afterwards) he led his daughter and son-in-law to a separate house with servants.
No one except one servant came close to him.
The sun set, day turned to evening, the time came to go to bed.
The wife prepared the linen, made the bed, they laid down to sleep.
The king's son put his sword by his side. The wife was surprised: "What's this about, why did he put a sword by his side [instead of me]?"
The king's son did not tell her that he was bidden to do so by a dervish.
And (he) fell asleep unperturbed.
The next day he once again put the sword by his side and fell asleep peacefully. For two days she tolerated (this), four days [passed], (and) for four days she tolerated (it).
The Russian translation adds "шесть дней терпела." ("for six days she tolerated [it]."), with no corresponding Wakhi.
On the seventh night, the king's daughter could not hold back, (she) embraced the king's son, broke the Dervish's interdiction, and went against his commands.
[All of a sudden] the king's son found himself out by the firewood,
with half a millet flatbread in his shirt, dressed in rags.
The king's son was surprised, wondering: "Was that all a dream, or did it happen for real, (and) what does it mean?
I killed a dragon, didn't I? Married a king's daughter, and now suddenly I find myself out by my firewood. Maybe it was all a dream?"
Here we will interrupt the tale about him.
The king's daughter awoke, (and exclaimed): "My husband is gone!" She started to cry.
When day broke, she went to her father and told him: "O father, last night my husband went missing, disappeared.
The door is locked, the windows are shut, the window in the roof is shut, but my husband is gone, what shall I do?"
The king said: "Decide for yourself, daughter, if you plan to search, I will give you servants, give you money, [and bid you] go forth, and search the cities for him!" The daughter agreed.
He gave (his) daughter money, a hundred people (as) servants, and loaded cloth upon a hundred horses, (and) gold and silver upon a hundred more horses.
And the daughter was on her way.
From village to village, from city to city, she looked for her husband.

Hoping to attract her husband, she paid ten rupees for milk that was (usually only) sold for two. [She did this] so that all the people in a village, however many, made a lot of money from her [and word spread she was there]. Thus she arrived at yet another town,
(and) the people gathered.
Her husband got some milk and came [with the rest, thinking], 'I ought to bring the merchant milk, [s]he will give me lots of money.
He came up to his wife (who was dressed as a merchant), and handed [her] a piala with milk.
She took the husband's piala of milk, (and) looked him in the face - it was definitely her husband's face.
Untranslated by Pakhalina.

She made a decision: "I'll learn about this man, he could really be my husband!" She sent away the other people, (but) she held him back, and said: "Stay at my camp for the night, you can help my servants, feed the horses, give them barley, and tomorrow I'll pay you in full."
The king's son agreed to stay for the night.
They had dinner and the time came to go to bed. (Then) she said: "Tell me (something) today, and I'll increase your payment tomorrow."
The king's son said: "I don't know what to tell you."
His wife, [the] merchant, said: "Perhaps you've had a dream of some kind, or heard some kind of a story from someone, tell me about that!"
The king's son said: "O sir merchant, one time, perhaps I was in a dream, perhaps it happened in reality, (but) here's the story I heard."
And he told everything from beginning to end.

When he got to the dervish saying that if he married he should not lie down to sleep with his wife for seven days, and then only after seven days he should lie down with her, his wife exclaimed: "O youth, it was not a dream you saw, this happened in reality!"

Right then his wife threw off her masculine garb, put on woman's clothes, said: "It's me, king's son, your wife, I wore men's clothes to search for you, and I give all thanks that I found you, I am your wife, Moidjon!
And you are my husband, Shaidjon!
Untranslated by Pakhalina.

You did not tell me that the dervish bade you not to lie down to sleep with your wife for seven days, I didn't know, could not hold back, embraced you, [and] have suffered many sorrows (because of it)!"
They took all of the wealth [that she had been carrying with her], and headed to the king's son's house.

Shoidjon's father and mother had become old and blind. His father's beard had grown white from sorrow: "My son is gone," [he had mourned]. (But now his son) rode up to the gate, and called out: "Father, mother, unlock the gate for me!"
The father and mother were puzzled: "Whose voice could it be?"
Shoidjon's mother said: "It's the voice of our son!"
The king said: "You are so stupid, wife, our son disappeared, he disappeared several years ago, we will never see our son again. (It's) just some [random] man who's come!"
He opened the door.
Shoidon flung himself at his father, kissed his hand, said: "I'm your son, I've been found!"
Shoidjon took out his kerchief, passed it over his father's face (and) the king grew younger once more and regained his sight.
He saw his son (and) rejoiced.
The king's son's wife took out her own kerchief, passed it over her mother-in-law's face (and) her mother-in-law once more came alive (and) regained (her) sight.
The father and mother embraced their son.
They were ever so happy.
They [began to] give away clothes and money to all the poor.
Their wealth grew greater than ever before.
People from (all the surrounding) villages gathered (and) came to the king's palace.
They made (the old) king (their) king again.
And Shoidjon became his father's vizier.
And they achieved their wish, and started living in happiness and prosperity.
And they had no need of God's help.
